text:
6 smart cities in which the future has already come
02 Nov 2019, 19:30 by Pasha Prokofiev
The technology in these places helps to cope with traffic jams, recycle trash and save lives.
1. New York
New York pays great attention to safety. The whole city is equipped with security cameras and microphones, which when the sounds of gunfire send a signal to the police. There is also a single open data system that ordinary developers can use. For example, startup HunchLab based on it created a tool for crime prevention. The system determines in which area and at what time it can be dangerous.
In 2014, massive Wi ‚Äë Fi was launched in New York. The routers were LinkNYC special terminals. With their help, you can go online, as well as recharge your smartphone or see the map on the built-in display.


LinkNYC terminal. crainsnewyork.com

The city saves on electricity: automated systems study the congestion of streets and control lighting based on the data obtained. A similar system, Midtown In Motion uses traffic information to regulate traffic lights, unloading roads at rush hour.
The bins in New York are also tech. They are called BigBelly and are equipped with sensors that send a signal to the utilities about a full tank.


Smart ballot boxes. bigbelly.com

The city is being improved not only through technology, but also through social programs. For example, one of them, Home ‚Äë stat, is aimed at employing homeless people. Every resident, seeing a tramp, can call social workers. Those will try to find a job for the needy person, and subsequently housing.
2. London
One of the main problems in London is car congestion. The city solves it with the help of investments in public transport, additional taxes on driving on weekdays and technology. The latter include smart parking, which informs drivers about free spots in the app, and a navigator program that advises the most convenient mode of transport depending on traffic congestion.


Sensor in smart parking. urenio.org

Technology welcomes London guests right at the airport: Heathrow Pods automated trailers go from one Heathrow terminal to the parking lot.


Heathrow Pods at the airport. afar.com

There is also a single open data warehouse in London - any information about the city is available to both ordinary residents and developers who can use it to create software products. The exact number of such applications is unknown, but in 2017 their number exceeded * over 450. The purpose can be different: from enrolling children in a queue in a kindergarten to participating in the city‚Äôs political life. * Source: London - The Dawn Of Tech ‚Äë rich Life Is Here
3. Copenhagen
The transport infrastructure of the Danish capital is designed primarily for cyclists. The so-called green wave works here: the system regulates traffic lights so that users of bike paths get to work in the morning and return in the evening without expectations. For the convenience of cyclists along the roads, inclined ballot boxes are located, as well as light indicators warning about the phases of the traffic light - so people know in advance whether they should slow down or speed up.



DriveNow's Copenhagen car-sharing service offers BMW i3 electric cars for rent, and the application will inform you if it is faster to reach your destination by public transport.
In the city you can find garbage chutes with a pneumatic waste system: all the garbage thrown into them is sucked into the remote storage by pipes. This allows you to get rid of garbage trucks on the road and keep yards clean.
Even the Amager Bakke incinerator can be called eco-friendly in Copenhagen. It produces energy for a nearby power plant and extracts water from condensate when burning garbage. And the roof of the building with a non-plastic coating acts as a year-round ski slope.


Amager Bakke Factory. dezeen.com

By 2025, the Copenhagen authorities plan to switch to a carbon-neutral economy and completely abandon fossil fuels. To achieve this goal will help solar panels and windmills, as well as the further distribution of bicycles and electric vehicles.
4. Reykjavik
While most smart cities are only striving to obtain electricity from renewable sources, Reykjavik has almost reached this goal: more than 70% of the energy here is extracted * by the geothermal method (from the thermal bowels of the Earth). * Source: Reykjav√≠k Smart City
Reykjavik residents use the Str√¶t√≥ service to drive around the city. In it you can not only get the best route, but also buy bus tickets and monitor the movement of public transport in real time.



Better is also popular in Reykjavik, a service where city initiatives can be offered. Over the 10 years of its existence, through joint efforts, more than 200 projects have been developed, which spent about 1.9 million euros from the municipal budget.
Fire departments and an ambulance in Reykjavik go to the call without waiting for the green light of the traffic light and without interfering with other traffic participants. The secret is that the Sitraffic Stream satellite prioritization system is used in the Icelandic capital. Each emergency vehicle has a sensor. When firefighters go to extinguish the fire, and doctors save the patient, the satellites track the position of their vehicles with an accuracy of 5 meters and switch traffic lights to green in advance.
5. Singapore
Singapore is one of the world leaders in population density. Therefore, they took care of installing cameras and sensors. They allow you to monitor the cleanliness of city streets, as well as more thoroughly analyze the flow of residents and cars on the roads.
Singapore was one of the first cities to launch unmanned vehicles and buses. By 2020, they want to equip each car with navigation systems and sensors - on a virtual map it will be possible to monitor the movement of all vehicles in the city.
All residents have access to local services using a special ID - a digital passport called SingPass.



Technology has penetrated the healthcare sector. Here, for example, a remote medical care system works. Doctors make video calls with patients: they consult about their condition, prescribe medications and recommend exercises, after which they follow the requirements with the help of cameras and sensors.
Sensors equipped apartments for the elderly. Devices send notifications to doctors and relatives if old people fall or do not move for a long time.
6. Seoul
The Seoul authorities are not introducing technology into the urban environment thoughtlessly, but after a thorough study of the behavior of residents. So in the city launched night buses. First, we studied the calls to taxi services, and then - the routes on which people traveled. The data obtained helped to map with areas where night transport is especially in demand. As a result, the city authorities managed to cope with the problem by running just 50 buses.
Also, OLEV electric cars were tested in the city. They are not charged from wires, but from the electrical network located under the road. Like a smartphone with wireless charging, only very large.


Electric Bus OLEV

Seoul residents are actively involved in the life of the city. All infobases are in the public domain. Any developers can use the data to create their services and applications, and each resident has a voice in discussing local reforms.
Almost every Seoul has smartphones and other smart devices: municipal authorities offer their own version of the trade-in program. Poor people can hand over old electronics and purchase new equipment at a discount.
However, not all experiments of Korean visionaries were crowned with such success. For example, Songdo, built 30 kilometers from Seoul, can be called the most technologically advanced ghost town.


Songdo ghost town. arup.com

The pneumatic waste disposal system, waste-free water supply and other advanced environmentally friendly technologies were supposed to work here. A 312-meter high Northeast Asia Trade Tower skyscraper was built in the city and a huge green area was built in the image of the Central Park in New York. But the city of the future did not cope with the main thing - did not attract people to itself.
